utterances: I did to a certain extent.
I'm afraid that in my case, it again came down to - as I said, there's two members in our family on active duty and for me, it came down to national security.
And who you trusted more as commander-in-chief.
And who I trusted more as commander-in-chief.
But that being said, now our new commander-in-chief is Barack Obama, and I've been praying for him all along and he will be the one that we pray for now and will honor and I'm very excited.
And as a Caucasian American, I don't think that I can ever get the intensity of what African-Americans feel right now but I felt a bit of that this morning.
It is historic and I'm excited that we've come to a place in our nation where every child can picture himself as president of the United States and you know that's exciting.
And I think that as Americans, we have to find those things that we feel in common with whoever the nominee is, whoever the commander-in-chief is, and try to get behind them on that.
I think that Senator McCain's speech was incredible - his concession speech - and we need to listen to that and we need to move forward.
Jeannie, we wish you and your family the best of luck.
Thank you.
Thanks very much for the call.
Let's see if we can go now to - let's go to another Republican caller.
This is Monique.
Monique with us from Charlotte, North Carolina.
CONAN: Hi.
Here, the new Consumer Protection Bureau does have the power to help by making it easier for bank customers to comparison shop.
I live in fear of karaoke.
My God, we're digressing.
OK.
(Soundbite of music)
I was just saying that one of the concerns that I have is the dynamics in terms of race relations whether they become worse because of the election and the way the election is being spun right now.
I had serious concerns in particular because I am black, I voted for McCain and based on my values, not necessarily on individuals, but I vote according to the issues and my values.
And so what concerns me is I don't watch the mainstream media; I do watch Fox News.

But even in watching Fox News constantly, what you see is this constant berating, this constant belittling of African-Americans so much so that it made me feel uncomfortable and I had to turn the TV off.

And so I really hope that eventually we can get to a point where we stop the race finger pointing and start looking at issues because I do believe that if things had been done differently, there's a possibility that some of the swing votes, including votes like mine, could have easily gone for McCain.

But in today's time and in today's age, when you don't want to see divisions and hatred and I mean just the - even every time they put a black person on Fox News or any other conservative news, they can't speak, they can't articulate points.
And so what happens is I get embarrassed and I feel like turn them off, get them off that radio.
They do not represent me or what I considered to be my mainstream.
They're nothing like the people that I've been around.
And you have other people who are not African-American and they're looking and saying, see, I told you they're just dumb.

They just voted for Obama because he's black when the truth of the matter is a lot of times they're voting a straight Democratic ticket because they're looking at this party that is spewing such hate and such venom and I don't think that those type of feelings need to be articulated in order to articulate a point in terms of values.
And Andy Kohut, I think Monique raises some interesting points.
Any thoughts on - any indications from the exit polls yesterday about what this is going to do for race relations in the country.
Well, actually the question was asked of respondents in the exit poll.
If Barack Obama is elected, what will happen to race relations?
A small plurality, 47 to about I think about 25 percent of whites, said they thought race relations would be better, but African-Americans were much more positive.
60 percent of African-Americans thought it would improve race relations.
Only ten percent said it would worsen them.
So there is a lot of hope and expectation that this will be a good thing.
Monique, thanks very much for the call.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
And before we go, we have talked about obviously the race for president of the United States and for the United States Senate.
Ken, there were 435 seats up yesterday in the House of Representatives.
Yes and I'm going to list everyone right now.
OK.
Do we have time?
Some things to mention.
In 2006, for example, not one Democratic incumbent was defeated or one Democratic seat went to the Republicans.
Yesterday, four Democrats in the House were defeated for reelection - Tim Mahoney, the congressman, the freshman from Florida.
Scandal-tainted.
With scandal who replaced Mark Foley was seated.
Who was scandal-tainted.
Don Cazayoux in Louisiana had a third party African-American candidate.
He won a special election this year - Democrat.
He lost a Republican.
Nick Lampson who won the seat that Tom Delay left in 2006 in Texas, he was defeated too.
Chris Shays, the Republican from Connecticut lost.
For the first time in history now, there is not one single Republican member of the House from New England.
It never happened before.
Republicans lost two House seats in New York State.
Now they only have three out of 29 - the lowest in history.
New Yorkers also - the Republicans lost control of the State Senate for the second time since the 1930s.
And William Jefferson - we talked about Stevens leading in Alaska and William Jefferson was re-nominated in.
William Cold-Cash Jefferson.
Exactly.
The money in the freezer under indictment is probably going to trial next month but he was re-nominated in an overwhelmingly Democratic district and will probably be reelected.
And one question here on email from Davis, California, Celeste.

How do you see your influence as the political junkie and the influence of your colleagues on various ends of the political spectrum as having had or not had an effect on the process and outcome of the election?

Well, I mean I think I suspect that there are some cable networks that like to preach to the converted, and I think what NPR has tried to do from the beginning is not so much - or that we did too much of this - worry about polls and worry about surveys but really get out and talk to what voters had to say about things.
No, wait.
I'm not insulting Andy Kohut.
But I mean we talk about - two years ago, we were talking about front runners and we talked about who was going to lead before voters even had the chance and that's crazy.

So I think what we had the opportunity to do - I think we did very well if I'm not patting ourselves on the back - is that we went out and heard what voters had to say, what they were concerned about and a lot of what we heard on the last couple of months I think was aptly indicated in yesterday's results.
And Andy Kohut, I'm going to give you the last word.
I'm going to turn to you and ask given this election, are we justified to think that this was historic as so many say maybe the most important election in our lifetimes.
If you look at the conditions of the country, if you look at the candidates, it would be hard to not think of this.
I mean this is a historic election clearly.
But let's also speak to the - give some credit to the voters.
The process was very long.
There was some presumption about who would be the candidates, how this would turn around, the media emphasizing those things 22 months ago, not of it turned out to be what happened.
The voters made up their minds and it was completely different than we would have expected 22 months ago.
Andy Kohut, thanks as always for being with us.
We appreciate it especially at the end of a very long, not only process but last 36 hours or so for you.
And Andy Kohut is director of the Pew Research Center for People and the Press, and he joined us here in Studio 3A.
Ken Rudin, NPR's political editor.
You can read his column, the Political Junkie, at npr.org.
He also joined us here in Studio 3.
Always nice to have you with us, Ken.
Thanks, Neal.
REP.
CATHY MCMORRIS RODGERS: (Reading) ...toy back.
He...
If the federal government's not going to cap fees or set specific prices on accounts, then we have to make sure that the competitive market really works.
And that means easy to get information for consumers on what bank accounts cost.
Scott Horsley, NPR News, Washington.
And now we bring you another alleged scam in the investment world.
It was announced this week.
Two New York fund mangers, Paul Greenwood and Stephen Walsh, have been charged with stealing over half a billion dollars from clients to support their lavish lifestyle.
They reportedly used the money to buy rare books, horses, a teddy bear costing $80,000.
That was, by the way, Steve, a collectible teddy bear.
(Soundbite of laughter)
The victims say they were told their money would be invested in an enhanced equity index and it would reap higher returns than the S&P 500, but it wasn't and it didn't.

The alleged scheme lasted upwards of a decade and the money was taken from college funds, including Carnegie Mellon University and the University of Pittsburg, which of course all of which is serious business.
I think my daughter would like to have the teddy bear when he's done with it.
Eighty thousand dollars?
Fine with me.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
Im Michele Norris.
And Im Robert Siegel.
The massive blizzard that swept the nation earlier this week has tested the resources and resolve of countless towns and cities.
And as NPR's Cheryl Corley reports, it dealt a blow to Chicago's can-do reputation.
It's bright and sunny in Chicago today, safe enough for Loyola student Lauren Smith to venture out.
Wow, it's crazy.
I actually haven't been outside since Tuesday.
Dont blame her.
The blizzard that hit here was the third worst in the city's history, dumping 20-plus inches of snow.
But Chicago has a nickname: the city that works.
And in an effort to live up to that model, city crews have been at it, nonstop.
Attorney Diane Elman(ph), walking to catch a train, says she's noticed.
I think it's pretty amazing.
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's impossible.
And a bicyclist rides by on a plowed and salted roadway, as if to emphasize the point.
